data.title: My affair with Douglas Adams and returning to my husband
data.meta_description: Sally Emerson left her husband for the author of the Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy books months after their marriage but soon realised it was a mistake.
data.text:
Sitting at breakfast with my husband and 21-year-old son this week, I read in the newspaper of the latest attack on marriage.

In her first speech, Dr Katherine Rake, the new head of the Family and Parenting Institute, an organisation set up by Labour to speak for parents and children, had announced that the traditional family unit - the nuclear family - was no longer the norm.

She predicted, too, that there would be no such thing as a 'typical family' in 20 years' time.

'Why?' I spluttered. 'How could we possibly cope without the family?' To my surprise, my son grudgingly agreed. 'It would be hard,' he said.

Perhaps he was humouring me out of politeness, but then that's one of the many things families are for - to encourage and humour each other.

Of course, I'm speaking from experience. But I believe that the traditional family so breezily dismissed by Dr Rake as well as by the (married) Children's Secretary Ed Balls - who's declared marriage is not the key to a happy family - is an institution that we cannot afford to cast out.

It isn't that the family is a pleasant extra, something that people candip into for amusement whenever they feel like it; rather, it's thatlife for all of us can, at stages, be unbelievably rough.

And during those rough periods, those times when we are crying outfor help, it is the family that we can count on to see us through.

Icertainly could never have managed through my life without the mutualsupport of a secure family structure. It would have been like beingthrown out to sea without a boat.

The irony is that Inearly blew family life out of the water. I came close to losing mymarriage early on. And every day I bless my good fortune in not doingso.

I'd known my husband Peter at university and we'd fallen in love. We'd lived together and got on tremendously well.

Then we got married and suddenly I felt I wasn't ready. I hated the wedding, really hated it. I loathed the idea of creating a future when I was only in my 20s.

Awful though it now sounds, the wedding seemed like a funeral to me. I loathed my stiff white skirt and top I'd bought at the last moment. I disliked the perfunctory ceremony at the Register Office. I hated the speeches. It all seemed to have nothing to do with me.

My memories of that day is one reason I recently compiled an anthology of writings, Be Mine, exploring love and marriage. Perhaps the right ceremony, with the right readings, might have helped.

Just a few months after the marriage, when my first novel was published in New York, I began an affair with Douglas Adams, the author of The Hitchhiker's Guide To The Galaxy. One of his catch phrases was Don't Panic, but the truth is that I'd certainly panicked over my marriage.

One reason I found him attractive was that he was a force of nature. He was obsessive and compulsive. Having him in love with me was like being carried off by a tornado. He was twice stopped by the police for kissing me while driving.

Before long I left my husband and we moved in together into a penthouse apartment with a roof garden and a bar in London's Islington.

The flat was very film starry, a far cry from the respectable married life which terrified me. What I didn't know then, of course, was that respectable married life isn't dull. It shifts and changes and throws bombs into your life when you least expect it.

It constantly makes demands, and if sometimes you feel you're in a boat rocking from side to side and it's hard to keep your balance, at least you have a boat to be in.

And even though the boat challenges you, you can suddenly find you enjoy the wind and sun in your face and that it's actually quite fun to try to keep your balance.

I found I missed my husband desperately. I missed his calm, his intelligence, his kindness, his support, so many qualities. Soon I wanted to return home. 'I can't rely on you,' I told Douglas. And it was true.

When I needed comfort from Douglas, it was like asking a black hole for comfort. He was romantic and funny, but much of the time in emotional freefall, which was the source of his genius.

Six months after I moved in, I told Douglas I was leaving him. He didn't believe me because he said I was The One and always would be.

He was going to make the dedication of his third Hitchhikers' book Life, The Universe And Everything, 'To Sally, who I love above the title.'

It would have been a typically good Douglas conceit, puzzling, then dazzling with its cosmic largesse - but after I left, it became 'For Sally'.

The One for me was my husband, I had decided by then, because he was the one I loved. And love is at the heart of marriage and the family.

But not just romantic love - complex, shifting and changing love for children, for grandparents, for funny old aunts who you put up with at Christmas because they are family.

What I hadn't realised when I packed my bags and moved in with Douglas is that love within a marriage can grow with time. I had felt in those early months after the Register Office ceremony that marriage made me smaller, that I'd become a little married woman.

But given time, marriage and a family can make you the whole bigger than the parts, a veritable force-field of times spent together, of memories and mutual interests.

It makes the members of that family unit enormously strong and - with luck - enormously happy. Marriage is about time, and when I left my marriage I had given it no time. Disraeli once said: 'There is no greater risk, perhaps, than matrimony, but there is nothing happier than a happy marriage.'

Forget moonlit nights and staring into each other's eyes, the real romance begins with marriage and progresses to children, and the family is a symbol of deep and eternal love, far more so than any gold eternity rings. It is, quite simply, magnificent.

This magnificence, this notion that family life is bigger, more exhilarating than anything I could have dreamed of when I embarked on it so reluctantly, is expertly described by the writer Ferdinand Mount: 'Marriage and the family make other experiences, both pleasant and unpleasant, seem a little tame and bloodless.

And it is difficult to resist the conclusion that a way of living which is both so intense and so enduring must somehow come naturally to us, that it is part of being human.'

Like any family, we have experienced big dipper catastrophes, when life seems to be shooting fast down into total horror. But they have made us stronger.

Some years ago my husband had cancer and the prognosis was poor. Forget us parents supporting our children; in this case, it was the children who supported us.

My daughter was 16 at the time and doing her GCSEs. Yet when I was too exhausted to go to the hospital, she'd say: 'I'll go!'

She brought him food, love and laughter in the grim hospital and she never complained, weeping only when I wept and she knew I needed someone to cry with.

Would Peter have coped without such constant love, or without the sweet face of his curly-haired young son who also attended his bedside? I don't know.

But he recovered. And the point is, it was all a joint effort; the whole family, the four of us, worked together to try to wrench someone we love from the jaws of death.

And since then, I've never thought of life as a breeze. I think it's wonderful and every minute must be cherished. But I've realised life can change at any minute, and that to cope with sudden change I want a loving framework of those I can trust absolutely to love me as I love them. A family framework in other words.

To those resilient individuals tough enough to survive without the help of this most cherishing of institutions, I offer my respect and wish them luck. I really do. But all I can say is that when the family works it feels right, profoundly right, and it gives a security and happiness beyond anything else.

My parents met at Cambridge University. They're in their mid-80s now. She was a beautiful English student, he a medical student.

My father is strong, determined, my mother brilliant and beautiful. Indeed, so clever she has just been awarded a medal for her work in Hut 6 in Bletchley Park during the war.

He adored her, she adored him, but at times over the course of their long, married life they fell out and quarrelled then loved each other again. And now my mother and father are more romantic than ever they were, though she's had a terrible stroke.

In hospital, she'd hear his footsteps coming down the corridor when he turned up at 8am every morning and she'd cry out his name (well, actually, my brother's name because the stroke has meant she muddled her nouns!) and he would say her name, Ceris, and he'd fall into her arms.

The staff said they were the most romantic couple in the hospital. My father has become a heroic figure, showing extraordinary reserves of resilience, patience and, above all, love for the woman he has adored all his life, through thick and thin, rich or poor, sickness and health.

To me, it is perhaps the pinnacle of human achievement, to love like that.

How dare anyone try to kick this mighty and protective institution of marriage aside when it encourages such love and loyalty and decency?

We have nothing to gain from dismissing the nuclear family. It is fun to attack it, of course, and attractive to blame your family for any faults you might have instead of accepting responsibility for your own life.

That's why people love Philip Larkin's phrase, 'They f*** you up, your mum and dad' - although letters he wrote to them when he was an undergraduate have recently come to light and they show he was really rather fond of them.

But I can't understand in whose interests it might be to allow this most ancient institution to crumble. The facts and figures of countless research studies are devastatingly conclusive: children with two devoted parents tend to do better at school and have fewer behavioural problems. It is not hard to work out why.

A government should not be trying to knock down the edifices which make us happy, but should be trying to build them up.

Chairman Mao, too, was keen on destroying the family and the relationship between child and parent, because it strengthened the state's hold on them and enhanced his own power.

p>In our house, where we've lived since 1993, there is the sense of the life lived here with the family, from the marks in the bathroom showing the children's heights to the old toys in the attic, maybe waiting to be played with again one day by grandchildren.

I don't envy great wealth and fame. When I saw pictures of the wonderful late historian Elizabeth Longford in her 90s, with her husband of so many years and her loving children and all her grandchildren, her family spanning the generations, I found that is what I wanted more than anything - these roots.

The long happy married life, the children, the memories, these are the glittering prizes after all. They don't come quickly and they don't come easily, but their worth is inestimable.
